text: In Carbo Verde, many coastal communities depend on small-scale artisanal fisheries for their livelihoods. But they face many challenges, including lack of technology, skills and organization. We have to pay for the fishing. We have to make a boat order to go back and pay for the fishing. We have to go to the beach. We have to pay for the fishing. We have to bring the fish to the beach. The biggest difficulty is the quantity of the fish. We don't know how much fish we have. We have to catch the fish. We don't know how much we have to grow. We have to know how to sell the fish, not one day. And to keep it in the cold, not always. We have to keep it in a place. For example, I don't have a boat. I can sell the fish all day long, even if I have a note. I have a lot of fish to keep. They are processing, marketing and community organizing. At the Fresco Mar Factory, they observed the process of manufacturing cantuna. They attended a demonstration of fish sorting and drying techniques at the Mendeo Municipal Fish Market. They also visited local fishers associations in Sao Pedro and Solamonza, where they learned how to create strong partnerships for better livelihoods. Today, maintenance and reforces this exchange with more visits, more exchange between women, more practical sharing, more difficulty sharing, more construction sharing and especially today, innovation that the association itself is finding to solve this problem.
